methods.name: calculateXPositionWithLineNumberOffset
methods.comment:
Calculates the offset of the x position for the given line number element.  The line
 numbers of the decompiler appear to the left of the data and thus offset the actual data
 by the width of the line numbers.  The line numbers may be disabled, in which case the
 given FieldElement will have no width.

params.name: initialX
params.comment: The original x value passed to the constructor of this class

params.name: lineNumberElement
params.comment: he line number element for this field from which we get a width

methods.name: calculateWidthFromXPosition
methods.comment:
Calculates the modified width for this field.  This is a factor of line numbers and any
 x offset given to this field element.

params.name: initialX
params.comment: The original x value passed to the constructor of this class

params.name: lineNumberElement
params.comment: The line number element for this field from which we get a width

params.name: initialWidth
params.comment: The initial width we are allowed to take up

return.comment:
the modified width for this field.  This is a factor of line numbers and any
         x offset given to this field element.

methods.name: getToken
methods.comment: Gets the C language token at the indicated location.

methods.javadoc: Returns the token that is completely after the token that contains the given column location. In this case, 'contains' means any position inside of a token, but not at the beginning. So, if the column location is in the middle of a token, it will return the index of next token. But if the column location is at the beginning (just before the start) of a token, it will return the index of that token. @param location containing the column at which to beginning searching @return the next token starting after the given column
methods.name: getNextTokenIndexStartingAfter
methods.comment:
Returns the token that is completely after the token that contains the given column
 location.  In this case, 'contains' means any position inside of a token, but
 not at the beginning.  So, if the column location is in the middle of a
 token, it will return the index of next token. But if the column location is at
 the beginning (just before the start) of a token, it will return the index of that token.

params.name: location
params.comment: containing the column at which to beginning searching

return.comment: the next token starting after the given column
